titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V: Saturday. Received this Morning a Letter from R. Aspland, in answer to the invitation I had sent him for the 22d. of last Month. He was absent from home, and did not receive it, till his return— I went into London, walked about four miles of the way, till overtaken by the Carriage. I called at Thomas’s Hotel, Berkeley Square, to see Mr Sergeant. I found Gabriel Shaw with him— A proposition was made nearly a year ago, by the House of Reid Irving and Co. through Mr Renwick to furnish ten Millions of specie Dollars to the Bank of the United States upon a deposit of United States six per Cent Stocks at par, and the Dollars to be delivered at four shillings and eight pence Sterling apiece. Mr Sergeant who is one of the Directors of the Bank, comes here deputed from that Institution to transact the business— He said he was waiting for the return of Mr Alexander Baring from Paris; and it was intended if he could agree with him that the whole business should be done by that house. I mentioned to him various considerations, upon which I thought it would be both just and politic to offer that the house of Reid, Irving and Co. should have a share in it.— First because the original proposition came from them; at a time when Mr Baring not only had no inclination to make any such proposition, but entertained opinions unfavourable to the establishment of the Bank, and avoided taking any interest in it— And very shortly after he had declined undertaking a loan for the Government of the United States upon terms far less advantageous to them— Secondly because the House of Reid, Irving and Company being in the Ministerial interest, and closely connected with the British Government, it would be useful to have them engaged by a strong interest to the preservation of Harmony, or at least of Peace, between
the two Countries.— He said that the Government of the United States were extremely satisfied with the manner in which the house of Baring had transacted their business— That there was a very strong feeling in America, in their favour. That the Bank had already been censured in the Newspapers, for passing by this old and tried friend and agent of the Government, to take up the proposals of an obscure and unknown house. That the object of Reid, Irving and Co. in making the proposal must have been to establish a strong American connection; probably to transact all the business of the Bank here in future; particularly to pay its dividends— That the Baring’s would naturally expect this themselves, and might think it hardly fair to them, if these advantages were transferred to another house— I said I was fully sensible of the merits of the house of Baring towards the United States, and should be anxiously desirous to do full and ample justice to them— I should by all means wish that they should have the offer of a share in this business— I had no personal acquaintance with any one individual of the House of Reid, Irving and Co. but the house was neither obscure, nor unknown. I had been informed upon making enquiries, that it was a house in great business and of the first respectability— The house of Baring had not been passed by. They had made no proposal— They might have made one as well as the other house— And as Reid, Irving and Co. did make the proposal, and the Bank were now acting upon it, I thought something was also due in justice to them— He said he would give due consideration to my advice. Mr Alexander Baring was the only member of the house with whom the business could be transacted. He could have the business now done upon terms more favourable to the Bank, than the original proposal of Reid, Irving and Co. owing to the change of circumstances since that time. Mr Baring’s return from Paris was not expected for several weeks; but it was now said that loan would fall through (which I doubt) and that Baring will be back in the course of a week— Sergeant was moving his lodgings from Thomas’s to N. 60 Conduit Street where the King’s lodged last Winter, I next went to my Office at Craven-Street where I found Letters, left there by John Smith Hollins of Baltimore, from John Spear Smith, and from C. Hughes at Paris. With them there was a French Book just published by Count Barbé Marbois, entitled “Complot d’Arnold et de Sir Henry Clinton, contre Les Etats-Unis d’Amérique, et contre Le Général Washington. September 1780[”]—which Hughes sent me. And there were copies for Mr Madison, Mr Monroe, and Mr Crawford— Mr Joy came and sat with us half an hour— I sat him down at the Corner of St. James’s Street, and Piccadilly, and reached home at seven. After dinner I read Cobbett’s Register. [symbols]

2. IV:15. My wife was unwell the whole day and kept her bed— The boys went to Meeting, and I to Church. Prayers were read for Septuagesima Sunday, with the addition only of the Collect, for the festival of the Purification of the Virgin Mary— This is one of the festivals, retained by the Church of England, and celebrated by all the Christian Churches, which keep any religious holidays— It is denominated in the Book of Common Prayer “The Presentation of Christ in the Temple; commonly called, the Purification of Saint Mary the Virgin[”]— Instead of the Epistle of the Communion Service the portion of Scripture appointed to be read is the first five verses of the 3d. chapter of the prophet Malachi— The Gospel of the day is Luke II.22–40. where the account of this presentation of Christ in the Temple was contained. It was in conformity to the Law of Moses, as prescribed in the 12th. Chapter of Leviticus, one verse of which is quoted in the narrative of St. Luke, who refers also to Exodus XIII:2. and XXII:29.— As the Birth day of Jesus is kept on the 25th. of December, that of his circumcision is of course fixed on the first day of January, being the eighth day after; and that of the presentation in the Temple, for the same reason is on the second of February, being the fortieth day from Christmas. Mr Carr read however the Epistle, and Mr Milman the Gospel, not of the festival, but of the regular Septuagesima Sunday. Mr Milman preached the Sermon, from Romans XII:16. the latter part of the verse. “Be not wise in your own conceits.” Mr Milman who is young, and wise enough to understand the road to preferment, is a fiery champion for the Church of England; but his wisdom has not taught him to make the application of his text to himself. His discourse was pointed against Unitarians and Methodists, but his only argument was that the Trinity, and the mysteries of the Christian Religion must be believed, exactly as they are prescribed by the Church of
England, because they are above the comprehension of uneducated persons— To prove which he quoted the passage in Milton which represents the Devils in Pandemonium, debating upon Fate, Freewill & Predestination without being able to come to a conclusion— But Milton’s devils, are represented by him as possessing intellectual faculties incomparably superior to those of the human species; and the Articles of the Church of England were framed by mere uninspired men. Now the Church of England have undertaken to draw conclusions, about Fate, Free Will and Predestination, which according to Milman’s Argument were as much above their comprehension, as above that of the most uneducated simpleton. They have been wise in their own conceits— He said that the Trinity was three modes of existence which from the poverty of language were called persons—and that eternity was an idea as incomprehensible as Trinity in Unity.— Upon which he quoted the text I am Alpha and Omega &c which no doubt are figurative expressions of eternity, but which if literally understood would prove that the first and last Letters of the Greek Alphabet, are God— It was amusing to hear Milton quoted in support of the Church of England; and a poetical fiction to confirm a religious dogma— After Church I wrote to G. Boyd, and to Gales and Seaton, and read the Introduction to Marbois’s History of Arnold’s plot.

3. IV:45. Note to Miss Clitherow informing her that I expect to be under the necessity of removing to London, in the course of a few weeks; probably by the beginning of March, and giving her notice according to our agreement, that after this day four weeks, Little Boston-House, where we reside, will be at her disposal. Also a Note of excuse to Countess Lieven, for my self and my wife, for not attending at her Evening party, last Evening, to which we were invited. My wife is yet unwell, and confined to her bed chamber.— Wrote despatch 70 to the Secretary of State. The boys had petitioned me to treat them with the sight of a Play at the close of their Holidays. We therefore took a cold Collation at two O’clock, and immediately afterwards went into London— I took with me the despatches to be forwarded to-morrow, and a Letter to the Proctors Cresswell and Addams with their Bills, which I send back to them to have regularly taxed— I had written to them last Saturday morning, that I thought this would be necessary, and Mr Addams called that day at the Office, and spoke with me about it— He was somewhat reluctant at suffering the Bills to go through this scrutiny, and said he was very sure the taxer of the Bills who must of course be the registrar of the Court, would reduce none of the charges, unless here and there one where thirteen shillings and four pence was charged, and where he might think the charge should have been six shillings and eight pence; and the whole reduction would not exceed, and perhaps not equal the addition, for the taxing fees. He also said it was not usual for Bills like these of the Proctors with their own Parties to be taxed; but only the Bills of Costs which are to be paid by an adverse party— And that they had sent me the printed Statements of the cases, shewing that General Lyman had defended the Causes in his official capacity, and that the Counsel and Advocates had been employed, for whose fees there were charges in the Bills— I preferred having the bills taxed, and was rather confirmed in that opinion by the unwillingness which Mr Addams, manifested to go through the operation— He said however it should be done by one of the deputy registrar’s of the Court, and suggested a wish that in sending back the Bills, I would write a note stating that it was to make merely the voucher regular— It struck Smith more than it did me, that the object of asking for this Note was to shew it to the taxing Officer, as a hint that he might relax from legal rigour in taxing the Bill, as the object in taxing the Bill was merely to comply with a formality. I took care in writing the Letter this day, to shew that it was a real and responsible taxing that I required.— Addams admitted that when they had been formerly employed by S. Bayard for the United States, he had always required that the bills should be taxed— But he said General Lyman did not. I left my Letter, and the bills with J. A. Smith, to be sent to the Proctors to-morrow— I found at the Office in Craven-Street, Letters from J. Maury, which I immediately answered—from Count Caraman, Secretary to the French Embassy, enclosing two Letters, which he has received from the Patterson’s at Paris, to be forwarded to the United States—and, from James Monroe a Letter of introduction to young Astor, which he has just left at the Office, but which is dated in November 1815.— We went to Drury-Lane, and saw Richard the third, with the Pantomime of Harlequin Horner, with a clown issuing from the Christmas pye— Kean performed Richard— The play is not exactly Shakespear’s— Colley Cibber, brought it out improved, and amended, and John Kemble has improved upon it again.— More than half the original Tragedy, including many of the finest Scenes is discarded— Two or three Scenes from the third part of Henry the sixth are transferred to this Play, there are modern Additions, not well adapted to Shakespear’s Style, and his language itself is often altered; and seldom for the better— As it is however, it has constantly been from Cibber’s time one of the standing favourites of the Public on
the English Stage, and the character of Richard is one of the trying tests of their greatest tragic actors. I never saw it performed but once before, and that was at Boston in 1794— It is by many of Kean’s admirers considered as his greatest part, but his performance this Night, in some degree disappointed me— There is too much of Rant, in his violence, and not smoothness enough in his hypocrisy. He has a uniform fashion of traversing the stage from one side to the other when he has said a good thing, and then looks as if he was walking for a wager. At other times he runs off from the Stage with the gait of a running footman— In the passages of high passion he loses all distinct articulation, and it is impossible to understand what he says— But he has much very good subsidiary pantomime, which is perhaps the first talent of a first rate actor. He has a most keen and piercing eye, a great command and expression of countenance, and some transitions of voice of very striking effect— All the other male performers were indifferent, and the women below mediocrity— The two children, girls, were very good— The Harlequinade has some good Scenery. There was a man introduced who performed a concert of six instruments at once— Bells in his cap—a range of pipes into which he blew; a guitar in his hands. Cymbals and Triangles fastened to his knees, and a drum slung at his back, with an elastic, drumstick fastened to his left elbow, bearing occasionally upon the drum’s head, as the elbow moved in playing upon the Guitar— The house was crowded, and the applause of Kean, incessant, during the Tragedy. The fight between Richard and Richmond, was skilful and vigorous— Kean always contrives to make a clap-trap of his dying scenes. The clapping at his death continued five minutes long. The Duke and Duchess, and Princess Sophia of Gloucester were present, and received with great applause. At their entrance God Save the King was performed by the Orchestra, and sung by part of the players, the Audience all standing. The entertainment finished just at Midnight, and it was near two in the morning when we reached home— I found an Answer from Miss Clitherow, and a Letter from W. Couling.

4. VIII: The boys returned this Morning to School. George came home again at three O’Clock, and walked with me before dinner to Brentford and through Sion House Park— My Morning was employed on the Journal of yesterday. By the Evening Post I received a Packet from W. Eustis—only a cover of a despatch to the Secretary of State. On the despatch was a minute by Eustis that the Ltre had been opened by him: and a request to me to cover it anew— His seal upon the cover was broken open— And there was a second Seal upon it, marked Comptrollers Office, Penny Post-Office— I had also a Letter from the wine Merchant D. Richardson. 96 Pall-Mall— My wife has been confined to her chamber since Saturday— The Misses Nicholas called here yesterday and this Morning but could not see her— This Evening she was so ill that I sent for Mrs. Hegg, our Gardener’s wife, and mother of our footman, William, to attend her as her Nurse— She sleeps in the chamber with her—

5. VII: And by day-light; I sent Antoine to London, for the Hogshead of Teneriffe Wine which he at last brought out; a full Month after the first application for the order from the Treasury. I wrote a Note to Count George Caraman; and Letters to my Mother, Brother, and to W. Couling. Received by the Evening Post a Card of invitation from the Spanish Ambassador, Count Fernan Nuñez, Duke of Montellano to a Ball on the 17th. Notes from Dr. Cooke of Gower Street, W. J. Burdett, and G. Shaw, and Letters from J. Maury and S. Bourne. There was a Ball, this Evening at the New-Inn at Ealing, which none of us attended; George, after some deliberation having concluded not to go. My wife was confined the whole day to her bed, but without suffering much pain— The crisis of her complaint lingers. We amused the Evening with Cards.

6. VI: Letter to F. E. Montreal at St. Petersburg— Went to London alone, and found at the Office in Craven Street, Mr Rotch and a Mr William Church, an American Citizen, an inventor, who wrote me in October last (v. the 14th.) asking for my patronage and assistance— As it contained no direction where to send an answer, I left the Letter unanswered, and had entirely forgotten it, until after he went away reminded of it by Smith— And even then had no distinct recollection of it— The Packet of Books from Philadelphia, was also at the Office, under a cover from the General Post-Office, sealed, directed to me, and superscribed, with Mr Freeling’s Compliments— Precisely at two O’Clock, I went with Smith and attended the Prince Regent’s Levee. We were not out of time, but quite late enough. The Levee was well attended, but not crowded like the first Levee last year.
The Prince Regent came in, before half past two, and was dressed in a blue Prussian General’s Uniform. The special Levee was over in less than ten minutes; the Prince spoke to very few persons, and a very few words to each— He passed on immediately and took his stand at the door for the general Levee, which was also over in the course of an hour. The foreign Ambassadors and Ministers were all there— As was the Russian Grand-Duke Nicholas— I mentioned to Count Lieven that I had not been presented to the Grand Duke, since his arrival in this Country. The Count said the Notification of his arrival had not been sent to me, owing to my residence in the Country. But that if I would give him notice at any time a day or two before hand, he was very sure the Grand Duke would readily receive me— I asked the Bavarian Minister, Pfeffel whether notice had been sent to the other Ministers of the Grand Duke’s arrival, and of the time when he would see them; or whether they had sent to ask to be presented to him— He said they had been notified— I do not feel myself therefore under any obligation to ask to be presented to him; and shall not put myself or him to inconvenience about it— General Kutusoff, the sometime Police Master of St Petersburg, and Baron Nicolaï are in attendance upon the Grand-Duke, and were present— The Spanish Ambassador Fernan-Nuñez asked me, if I had received the Card of invitation to his Ball— I had, and told him we purposed attending it. The Dutch Ambassador Fagel, said if I did not return this Evening to the Country, he should invite me to an Evening party at his house. He gives a dinner to the Prince Regent, and the Grand Duke Nicholas, and the Evening party afterwards. I asked the Portuguese Ambassador Count Palmella, if the late Newspaper reports that the King of Portugal intended to return next Summer to Lisbon were true— He said he believed there was no foundation for them whatever— That the king was to be crowned next April, in Brazil. That the Austrian Archduchess Leopoldine was going there; and that it would not even be prudent for the king to return to Europe while the Spanish Provinces all around him were in a state of revolt against Spain— The Count spoke to me in very respectful terms of Mr Correa de Serra, now the Portuguese Minister in the United States— Jouffroy the Prussian Chargé d’Affaires told me that he had lately heard from St. Petersburg. That Clementine Bode, was married to young Livio. Jouffroy has been in ill health, and has much fallen away since I left him in Russia. Count Caraman, thanked me for the Note which I sent him this morning, and which he had received. The Duke of Gloucester asked me, if I had heard from the Patterson’s at Paris. The Earl of Westmorland enquired also about them, and told me they had spent considerable time with him at Althorp his Country-Seat—that they had made themselves universally beloved by every one, who had become acquainted with them. That while they were with him, Mr Patterson had gone for a few days into Leicestershire to a fox-hunting party, which was quite a new and extraordinary Scene to Patterson— And he gave me a ludicrous account of his having supplied Patterson an old, broken down hunter to mount, and of Patterson’s inability to manage him. He asked whether they intended to return soon from Paris; and how they were pleased there— I told him I heard they were to return very soon; but they were very well pleased with Paris; as the Duke of Wellington, who was King of Kings there, had taken much notice of them and thus introduced them to all the good Company. The Earl then commenced upon Politics, and asked me about the harvest in America— I told him that it had been indifferent, and that my Letters complained that the great exportations of flour from the United States to this Country, were increasing the prices there to an alarming degree. He said it was so much the better for America. That the first and greatest policy for a Country should be to encourage the cultivation of grain so as to raise a sufficiency for their own consumption. That he was thoroughly convinced almost the whole distress of which the people in this Country were complaining had arisen from the importation of Corn, as I expressed some little surprize at this opinion; he repeated it; adding that he did not mean to deny that there were other Causes, contributing to the effect, particularly the sudden transition from War to Peace and the great numbers of People, thereby thrown out of employment (not a word about the debt and taxes) but the great and effectual cause was the importation of foreign corn, which by reducing the price below what the farmer could afford to sell for, disabled him from employing workmen, and from applying his capital to the improvement of cultivation. I observed to him that the price of corn had now risen again sufficiently sure to encourage cultivation and the employment of workmen. He replied that it was too late, the mischief was done— The farmer had lost his capital, which had been wholly sunk. He possessed no longer the means of paying labourers; the rise in the prices therefore had increased instead of diminishing the evil— The prices now were too high; and the poor were suffering, in both ways; on one side by the want of employment, & on the other by the dearness of the necessaries of life— The commerce of the Country had suffered comparatively speaking nothing. Their commerce of exportation had actually suffered very little— Just as he was upon these remarks some person came and called him away— I soon after left the Levee -Room and retired.— Sir Robert Liston was waiting to receive immediately after the Levee, the investiture of Grand-Cross of the Order of the Bath, together with Sir Gordon Drummond. As I passed through the first Anti-room I spoke to the Lord Mayor, who had presented an Address from the Common Council
of London, to the Prince Regent, on his providential escape, from the bullets, stones and potatoes, discharged by the mob at the State Carriage, on his return from the House of Lords, after opening the Session of Parliament— On returning to Craven Street, I found a Note from the House of Baring’s mentioning that the Articles to be shipped for Mr Boyd, are to be sent by the Electra, for Philadelphia, to sail about the 15th. of this Month.— A person from Cresswell and Addams, Proctors of Doctors Commons, brought me a Letter from them, with the Bills, that I had returned to them, now sent back taxed by a Deputy Registrar of the Court. He has deducted about five Pounds Sterling from each of the Bills; but they have now advanced another, and a new demand of £170 Sterling, of which I had never before heard— I took it for consideration— Suter the man who first came with a pretence of relationship, and next for a loan of money, offering his bill upon Philadelphia, came again this day, as a plain beggar, with a petition drawn-up for him by Mr. Sergeant. I left the Office a quarter before five, and walked until overtaken by the Carriage in Hyde-Park— I reached home about seven.

7. VI:30. With the dawn— The journal occupied all the Morning, and after a walk to Gunnersbury Acton and Ealing, I wrote Letters to Cresswell and Addams, and to F. Freeling, Secretary to the General Post-Office— In my walk I met & walked some way with Mr Milman— By the Evening’s Post I received a second duplicate of W. Shaw’s Letter to James Grubb; and Smith sent me out a card of H. H. Joy, and a Note from G. Joy to Smith, asking of Mrs Adams, a spare ticket for H. Joy to Prince Esterhazy’s Ball, this Night; he having heard that all the foreign Ministers had lots of tickets to distribute— We had no invitation to this Ball ourselves— My wife has been quite ill the whole day, and this Evening severely. She has long complained of a pain in the right side, and it has become so sharp that this afternoon by the advice of Dr Cook, she had seven leaches applied on the spot, which drew much blood; at the stopping and turn of which she was in great pain and faint. She afterwards recovered, but remained very weak— I was up with her till near Midnight— The weather continues mild— This day I saw the Snow-drops, daisies, and several other flowers in blossom in our garden. The leaves of the honey suckle are putting forth, and almost disclosed—and vegetation advanced far beyond any thing I ever witnessed so early in the Season. I marked the blossoming of the Crocuses and Snow-drops last year as unusually early on the 21st. of February. This year the Crocus blossoms appeared the 27th. of January.

8. VI: Letter to Grubb, enclosing that received for him last Evening— Began also a Letter to B. Waterhouse from whom I have had three upon file several Months; but part of this morning was idled away, and I took a walk with George of near two hours to Hangar Hill. By this Evening’s Post I received an answer from Grubb, and Letters from my Mother and brother, with several for George: also a Letter from James Maury, who mentions having forwarded by the mail a packet for me from the Department of State— John and Charles came home to dinner, and returned to School in the Evening. My wife was still confined almost the whole day to her bed. She rose only to dine, and immediately after dinner fainted, and was obliged to return to bed.

9— V:30. I now receive on Sunday Mornings, the Courier, Cobbett’s Register, and the Literary Gazette of Saturday, and the Observer and Examiner of the day. It employs no small portion of the day to give each of them a cursory glance. I barely found time this day to finish my Letter to Dr Waterhouse. I attended Church alone. Prayers for Sexagesima Sunday were read by Mr Carr— The Sermon by Mr Milman from Matthew VII:21. “Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in Heaven.” The discourse turned entirely upon the manner, in which, Lord, Lord, ought to be spoken— After Church, I called at Dr Nicholas’s, which he had yesterday desired George to ask me to do. He introduced to me a Mr Thomas Smith, a young man of this neighbourhood, who was formerly one of the Doctor’s pupils, and is now going to travel upon the Continent of Europe, in Holland, Germany, Russia, and France; and for whom he wishes to obtain Letters of Introduction— The Doctor’s third Son, Edward, who usually resides in Wales, but is now here, came in for a few minutes but was not introduced to me. Major Fortnam was there; and Mrs Wetherall with her daughter. The Dr. first mentioned to me that a paragraph in the Observer of this day, announced accounts from the United States of the decease of A. J. Dallas, late Secretary of the Treasury— I found it so, on my return home. He is said to have died of the cramp in the Stomach— The Accounts from New-York, are to the 18th. of last Month.
I had a visit from General Boyd and young Storer, from London— On mentioning the Account of Mr Dallas’s death, I found that Boyd was much embittered against him. He said the army had been much dissatisfied with the influence Dallas had had in determining the Officers who should remain in service after the reduction. Boyd himself was left out although he had been of the army before the late War.— He now spoke of Dallas very unfavourably and countenanced several imputations which have lately been brought against him in the United States— He told me that he should call upon me in town to-morrow. R. Chichester, George’s school mate, dined with us. His brother James has sent George, a present of a couple of Hares. My wife has been better, and was up several hours— I received this Morning a Letter and account from Richardson of Pall-Mall.

10. V:30. I sent the Carriage to London, to Messer and Page the Coachmaker’s, for some necessary repairs; and Antoine with Notes, to Count Fernan Nuñez the Spanish Ambassador, accepting his invitation to a Ball, next Monday, to the Baring’s with a box of plants for G. Boyd to be shipped by the Electra for Philadelphia, and to A. Loughnan, enquiring whether the order from the Treasury had been received by the Commissioners of the Customs and Excise, for the delivery to me free of duty, of the Pipe of Madeira Wine that I had purchased of him— I walked to London in 2 hours and 43 minutes from my house door to the door of my Office 28. Craven Street— I found there a Letter from James Maury. Two Packets of National Intelligencer from the Department of State, but forwarded by him; and a Letter for G. Boyd, under cover to me— General Boyd soon after came in. He is pursuing here some claim upon the East India Company, and wishing to give himself consequence requested me to present him at Court, which I promised to do. He enquired if he might with propriety appear there in the Military Uniform. I supposed he might. He said he had never had any other profession, and had now a Memorial at the War Office, claiming to be reinstated in his rank, or to stand as a candidate for reappointment when a vacancy shall occur. He also requested me to present his nephew Mr Storer to Court, as he thought it would give him eclat. I likewise consented to this. There were a succession of other visitors to the Office— Mr French with Mr Moore, Irishmen; the latter a naturalized Citizen of the United States, settled at Baltimore. He is going next week to Liverpool to embark for that place and offered to take for us Letters or despatches. Mr Addams of Doctors Commons, who came to give explanations about a new demand against the United States, advanced by Cresswell and Addams, just as I was about settling their former claim— It was for a Case unfinished at the time of General Lyman’s death; afterwards managed by Mr Beasley, and which upon his bankruptcy they had proved as a debt against his Estate— I had no authority to admit this claim; and I requested Mr Addams to furnish me a copy of their general account against General Lyman, to the balance upon which only they have hitherto referred— After some hesitation he promised I should have it— J. M. Forbes, called to ask me to pay an engraver’s Bill of £36:16. for engraving two forms of Passports and a Seal, and for a Press to the seal, which he has procured here for his Consulate in Denmark— A person by the name of Kent, belonging to the Society of Friends, a workman in ornamental architecture, came to make enquiries whether he could obtain employment in his occupation in America. I told him I had no doubt he could. He said his business like all others was here so dead, with a prospect that things were only going from bad to worse, that he had a strong inclination of removing to America probably to Philadelphia, where there are many Quakers, and where the climate would suit his Constitution better than more to the Northward— He asked me if I had seen a Letter from America, printed in a Newspaper at Stamford, saying that whatever might be the distress in this Country, it was twenty times greater in the United States. I had seen many such paragraphs & Letters published in the Newspapers, but I told him they were misrepresentations, published for the purpose of checking the emigration to America— A man named Levi came to enquire if we had received a Commission for two Merchants to ascertain the real value of certain merchandize sent by him to New-York, and there seized at the Custom-House on the allegation that the value of the Articles was underrated in the invoices— The Commission he said he supposed would be transmitted through my hands, but I have not received it— He complained that the charge upon which the Articles were seized, had been brought by merchants who had imported similar articles themselves, and that their object was merely to monopolize the market— The articles in question were of jewelry— Messer the Coachmaker came to tell me of sundry repairs necessary for the Carriage; and G. Joy called for the sake of Conversation— There was a Spa-fields Meeting of the people in distress, which had greatly alarmed the Government, but it passed off without any tumult or disorder— The Coachman came with a Carriage from Messer and Page’s— Antoine had been too late for the Office of the Commissioners of Customs and Excise, and returned without accomplishing the business upon which I had sent him— Just before seven I got home and found, a letter from J. M. Forbes, containing the same request that he had verbally made; that I would pay his engraver’s bill— A note from Leslie, proposing to send the Pictures by the Electra, and asking me to call and see them— And a Note from Mr Cooke, under Secretary of State at the foreign Department; saying that the orders have been given from the Treasury for the delivery to me of two Hogsheads of wine, instead of one Pipe as had been directed by mistake— But this is another blunder— I asked for one Pipe of Madeira
and one Hogshead of Teneriffe— The Order given was for one Hogshead of each— Either Cooke himself has made a mistake or I shall have to apply again— I dined alone, and in the Evening read some of the National Intelligencers. My wife is better, but still confined to her chamber.

11. VI: Wrote despatch 71 to the Secretary of State; but as it was not ready to be sent by the Morning’s Post to Smith, I kept it, to give to him to-morrow. Walk with George to Isleworth and through Sion House Park. I began the examination of Coll: Aspinwall’s Accounts of expenditures for the relief of destitute Seamen, which he transmitted to me some time ago— They amount to near ten thousand Pounds Sterling for the year 1816— I also received yesterday J. Maury’s accounts and vouchers for the last four Months expences at Liverpool on the same account— This Morning and Evening I passed some hours in reading the National Intelligencers yesterday received— I had by the morning Post a Letter, from F. Freeling, Secretary to the General Post-Office— He says the Packet of Newspapers which I declined taking last October, and returned to the Post-Office has been destroyed. In the Evening I received a Letter from J. Ramsey Cox dated at Walmer, enquiring if I could relieve and send to America, W. West, a native American and his wife, now supported as paupers at that place.— In my walk, I met Mrs & Miss Clitherow, who were coming to enquire of the health of my wife. She continues better, but cannot yet leave her chamber.

12. V: Letters to my Mother, to J. R. Cox, and J. M. Forbes— Notes from and to the Brothers Baring and Co. and to Leslie. Received also a Letter from Cresswell and Addams, enclosing a copy of their Account against the Estate of Genl: Lyman and a Note from Sir Grenville Temple, brought out by J. A. Smith. He brought also a Letter from J. Maury, to Moss, Dale, Rogers and Moss, Bankers at Liverpool, mentioning that he had requested me to pay to Barclay Tritton and Co. £296:1: the amount of the Bill that he has lately sent me, and desiring that they would if required sign receipts for the money— I had a company of Gentlemen to dinner, Messrs. Aspland, Birkbeck, Buchanan, W. J. Burdett, Dr Cooke of Gower Street, Frend, Hollins, Rotch, Sergeant, G. Shaw, J. A. Smith, and Watmough— The boys had obtained permission to come home from school, and dined with us— It was my wife’s birth day; but she is yet confined to her chamber, though recovering. Mr Birkbeck asked my permission for George to go and visit him at Guilford. Mr Sergeant said he would call on me at my Office in Craven Street to-morrow, to speak with me on the subject of his business. The company left us about half past ten.

13. VII: At J. A. Smith’s request I wrote a Note to Mr Wellesley Pole the Master of the Mint; asking of him an order to see it. Went to London with John and Charles. Stopp’d at Richardson’s in Pall Mall, and settled his account. At the Office in Craven Street I found a packet of Books from New-York, sent byCaldwell, intended for G. Boyd, and Coll: Fenwick at Bordeaux. They had the Postmark of Ship Letter, from Gravesend, charged as 43 ounces, with £10:0:8. postage. I sent it back with a Note to F. Freeling—Secretary to the General Post-Office. I went to an auction of books and mathematical and philosophical instruments in Chancery lane; and from thence to Mr Leslie the Painter’s, where I saw the Portraits of Mrs Adams and me which he has painted, to be sent to T. B. Johnson at New-Orleans. He sends them first to Philadelphia— I paid him the balance due upon them; and returned to Craven Street— Mr J. Sergeant had been twice there while I was absent. There was a Letter from J. M. Forbes, and a Note from Sir Benjamin Hobhouse, requesting me to forward to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, some volumes published by the Bath agricultural Society—this Note was immediately answered. Mr Frend called and brought two tickets for a dinner of the religious Tract Society, at the London Tavern next Monday. He said the Meeting would consist of persons of all religious denominations about a hundred in number, and that Mr Aspland & Mr Jones Burdett would be there. I declined however accepting for myself; but Mr Frend left two Tickets with Smith. Mr Frend disclosed some of his peculiar opinions, which are very decisive against all religious establishments, and even against any existence of the clergy as a distinct profession. He has an abhorrence of Priests of every description, and earnestly recommended that we should never suffer any of them to be Presidents or Professors at any of our Universities or Colleges. He said that the dissenters were so constantly, and so rapidly increasing in numbers in this Country, that in the course of a few years they would form a majority of the People— That the establishment would then fall, and was indeed already crumbling in to ruin. And when once abolished that which
now forms the revenues of the Church will constitute a fund to relieve the Country from a large part of the taxes which now bear upon it. All this he said was implied in two Greek words introduced into a Note of his pamphlet lately published, and he asked me if I had understood them— I called at the Engraver Silvester’s with a Seal. We came home, about seven— The new silver coinage was issued this day; and is very indifferently executed— After dinner I read the two Numbers of Hone’s Reformists Register; a publication in close imitation of Cobbett’s, and written altogether in the same Spirit. John and Charles returned this Evening to School.

14. VII: George was very ill all last Night, and continued so unwell that he did not attend school this day. Mrs Adams for the first time since her illness rode out and he went with her— I was myself so much disordered with indolence that I wrote only the journal of yesterday— Part of the morning slipp’d away in examining my brothers accounts. I walked to Brentford, through Sion-House Park and Isleworth— Received by the Evening’s Post a Card from Prince and Princess Esterhazy to an Evening party next Thursday— Read the Monthly Review in the Evening.

15. VI:30. Richardson’s cellar-man was here.— Examined my brother’s accounts. Went to London with George, and left him at number 15 Sackville Street, the lodgings of General Boyd and Mr Storer— He had engaged to go with Storer to see the British Museum; and to dine with him; but it proved that the Museum was not open this day. As we were going to town we met the Postman before we reached Brentford, and he gave me a Letter from F. Freeling. He says My Lords the Post-Masters General, have authorized him to reduce the postage of £10:0:8 on the Books from Brentford to £l.— After stopping at Richardson’s, I went to Craven Street, where I found the packet of Books from Sir Benjamin Hobhouse for the American Academy, and a Letter from my brother of 13. January. Mr Storer shortly after came and enquired after George, who was at his lodgings. A Mr Babcock of New-York came with the printed papers of a case which he has pending before the Lords of the Council; an appeal from the Vice Admiralty Court, at Nassau, New Providence— By the second Article of the Treaty of Ghent, hostilities at sea, were to cease twelve days after the ratification, on all the Coast of North America, from Latitude 23 to 50 North, and as far as the 36th. degree of West Longitude—and thirty days after the ratification, in the Gulph of Mexico and all parts of the West-Indies— Babcock and others were owners of a vessel, bound from New-York to the Havanna, taken about twelve minutes North of Latitude 23, and in sight of the Havanna, after the expiration of the twelve days from the Ratification but within the thirty. She was carried into Nassau, and was there ordered to be restored, with the Cargo, as having been taken after the stipulated cessation of hostilities— The captors appealed, and Dr. William Adams is engaged as Counsel for them on the appeal. Mr Babcock said he called upon me, by the advice of Mr S. Williams; and that his advocate Dr Arnold advised a compromise with the captors. I said nothing on that subject but on looking at the map the case appeared to me so clear in favour of the decision of the Court of Vice-Admiralty, that I thought it must be affirmed. Mr Babcock told me he would inform me what the judgment of the Court of Appeals might be. Mr Grubb afterwards called with a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall, and the accounts for cloathing and medical attendance for destitute American Seamen during the year 1816. and a large bundle of vouchers amounting to more than two thousand pounds Sterling. Grubb said that there had been in the course of the year not less than 1400 applications of Seamen for relief. More than had been made in seven years before the late War. I asked him if they could ascertain the causes of this extraordinary increase. He said they were various; there had been an unusual number of shipwrecks the last year. Besides which many of the vessels fitted out as privateers during the late war had been sent to the Havanna, and there sold, to be employed in the Slave trade— The American Crews were discharged when the vessels were sold, and then found their way to this Country in English vessels— I desired Grubb to ask Coll Aspinwall to send me a statement of the numbers of applications for relief during the year—of the numbers that received relief. How many were sent home by Cartels, and how many by merchant vessels: with a statement of the relative numbers of white and of persons of colour; and the principal causes of their having been brought to this Country, and in the condition to need relief. I left George in London; walked to Kensington Garden Gate; and on reaching home at seven O’Clock found John and Charles again here. A Letter from A. Loughnan to inform me that the Pipe of Madeira wine would be ready for delivery on Monday; and a Letter from C. Hughes, at Paris to introduce Mr D’Arcy, who was with Mr Pinkney, on his late Mission to Naples— D’Arcy left the Letter at the Office, from whence it was sent out this Morning by the Post— In the Evening I read Hone’s Reformists Register, and Cobbett’s weekly Pamphlet.

16. V: As George, with whom Charles usually sleeps was last Night absent, Charles slept in my bed; but I had a sleepless Night myself, and rose this morning at five. The sky was clear and I saw from my Cabinet windows the Stars of Libra, Antares and the principal Stars of the upper part of the Scorpion. The Serpent and knees of Ophinchus, and the head of Poniatowsky’s Bull. The
dawn was already far advanced, as this day the Sun rose at seven and set at 5. O’Clock, Jupiter is yet within five degrees of Antares— I wrote a Letter to my brother, and attended Church. Mr Milman read prayers for Quinquagesima, or Shrove Sunday, the Sunday before Lent. He gave notice that the Church Service would be performed, every Wednesday and Friday during Lent. He also read the form of Prayer and Thanksgiving which has been appointed to be read at morning and Evening service, two Sundays successively, for the Prince Regent’s escape from the stoning of a lawless Multitude— The prayer is also that he may be saved from the madness of the People; with a side glance against the Petitions for Parliamentary Reform. But Milman forgot to read the prayer for the High Court of Parliament. The Sermon was preached by Dr Goodenough from 1. Corinthians III.11. “For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ.” A plain, sensible, but superficial discourse. Dr Goodenough both for matter and manner is upon a level of ordinary mediocrity— I walked before dinner to Brentford and through Sion-House Park. George walked home from London. After dinner, John and Charles returned to School. The Sunday Papers took up too much of my time. My wife was again very ill all last Night, and confined to her chamber all this day. Mr Cooper was here to attend her instead of Dr Cooke his partner, who since last Monday has been himself confined with an inflammatory fever. Mrs Hegg went home last Tuesday.

17. VI:30. By full daylight. Sent Antoine to London for the Pipe of Madeira wine which he finally brought out; together with the box, for Mrs Adams that G. Boyd brought from France, and which has since then been lying at the Custom House. I received by the Evening’s Post a Letter from G. Boyd at Paris, returning me the blank Order upon the Secretary at War, signed— He had forgotten to sign it when he sent it to me before. Also an order from a Mr Morrison, deputy Master at the Mint, for me, with five friends to see the works at the Mint, next Thursday; which being the day of the Drawing Room, I cannot then go— I left home at nine this Evening, and went to Count Fernan Nuñez, Duke of Montellano, the Spanish Ambassador’s Ball— I made up a Packet of Newspapers, for the Secretary of State, and a Packet to my Father, containing a Letter to my brother from me, two from George, one to my Mother, and one to Claudius Bradford, and also some Newspapers: I took them with me in the Carriage, and on alighting at the Ambassador’s, told my footman William Hegg to carry them to Mr Smith at Craven-Street. I also left in the Carriage my round hat and my surtout. When I came out to return home, on entering the Carriage, and driving off, my hat was missing. On enquiring for it, William told me that it had been stolen from the Carriage together with the packets of Papers, while he was riding with the Coachman on the box, from the Ambassador’s house, to Cavendish Square. The Surtout luckily escaped. At the Ball, there were between three and four hundred persons, among whom the Dukes of York and Gloucester, the Grand Duke Nicholas; several of the Cabinet Ministers; all the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers, Earl Gray, Lords Erskine & Holland, Sir Robert Liston, Sir Gore Ousely &c— More Gentlemen than Ladies. The Prince Regent was to have been there, but sent an excuse this morning. It was said he had the Gout. I had scraps of conversation with most of the foreign Ambassadors & Ministers and particularly with Mr Poletica, who is now a Counsellor of the Russian Embassy here. He told me he did not think Mr Daschkoff had been recalled from the United States, though he supposed he ultimately would be— I spoke also to Lords Westmorland, Gray, Erskine and Holland—to Lady Castlereagh and Mr. Planta, and to Mr Chester— The only dansing was of Quadrilles. I came away at half past twelve; and got home a quarter after two— It seems that the glass windows were stolen from several Carriage— There was a crowd of People before the house, and no strange Servants admitted into it.

18. VIII:30. The day was idly wasted— The loss of my Letter to my brother makes it necessary to copy it, and I barely found time to begin the copy. Walked with George through Sion House Park before dinner. I passed much of the day and all the Evening in my wife’s chamber, to which she is still confined. And two or three hours were absorbed in reading the debates of last Evening in the House of Commons. Discussions about Brougham’s declarations heretofore in favour of annual parliaments and universal suffrage; and about Croker the Secretary of the Admiralty’s obtaining a War Salary during the time of Lord Exmouth’s last expedition against Algiers. Both these Gentlemen are distinguished personages, on the political theatre at this time; they were both vigorously attacked last Night, upon points affecting their personal reputation; and both made most lame and impotent defences. Croker is one of the Scavengers of the Ministry—a Quarterly Reviewer, a Courier Scribbler, and above all an inveterate and rancorous enemy to
America. He is Secretary to the Admiralty, and obtained from the Lords an increase of his Salary for a whole quarter on the pretext of the two days of Algerine War— Lord Milton’s motion in the house of Commons last Night was for a vote of censure upon the Lords of the Admiralty for having allowed this increase— The motion was lost by 169. to 114. votes which is considered as a very small ministerial Majority, and a very large minority. Lord Grey, Lord Holland and Planta, all spoke to me of it last Night: Grey considered it as a proof of the weakness of the Ministry— Planta said it was a very large minority; and that there ought never to have been any occasion for the Motion— Holland said that it was a bad minority; and a worse majority; because it shewed there were many of the ministerial members who would not vote on this question. Brougham is a violent opposition member, who has gone out of his way this Session to attack the Reformers who petition for Annual Parliaments and universal suffrage— He said last week, that they might be divided into two Classes—the deceivers and the deceived. The reformers have retorted upon him, by publishing a speech made by him in 1814. at a London Tavern dinner; in which he declares himself in favour of annual Parliaments and Representation, co-extensive with taxation— Lord Cochrane read last Night in the house of Commons an extract from this speech— Brougham’s only defence was that he had meant direct taxation. The whole Opposition in Parliament, are running themselves down to nothing in the popular opinion.

19. V:15. I finished the copy of the Letter to my brother and began despatch 72 to the Secretary of State. The weather being fine, my wife took a ride. She is yet quite unwell. I walked to Brentford, and round by Sion-Hill and Osterley Park and found the distance by my watch just seven Miles; a two hours walk. By the Evening’s Post I received under cover from R. Chester, Assistant Master of the Ceremonies, a Card for my Carriage to enter St. James’s Park to-morrow, at Constitution-Hill, to go to the Queen’s Drawing Room.

20. VI:15. I went alone to London, and found at my Office in Craven-Street a Letter from James B. Church signing as Consul of the United States at Cork; asking instructions concerning the relief to be afforded to the Crew of a ship wrecked American vessel: and one from Silas Richards of the House of Ogden, Richards and Selden at Liverpool, about the time when the repeal of the discriminating duties should commence, by the Convention of 3. July 1815— Also two Bills of Exchange, drawn by my brother upon me; dated Boston 11. January 1817. in favour of William Gray; one at 60 days sight for £600 Sterling, endorsed by David Greenough, after W. Gray, and Abram Rhodes and Co.— The other at 30 days sight for £500. same date and endorsers. They were left at the Office on Tuesday, by a Clerk from the House of T. & S. Nicholson, Janson and Co. 32. Abchurch Lane; for a House at Leeds; with a request that they might be accepted as on Monday the 17th: as they had then been presented at the Consul’s Office— I accordingly accepted them payable by S. Williams; one, 22. March. the other 21. April. And I signed a Letter to S. Williams giving him notice of them— Forbes had also left his Letter of Credit upon the Willink’s and Van Staphorst’s at Amsterdam, for 2000 dollars a year, Salary as Agent of Claims at Copenhagen, to commence from the 16th. of May last, the original being signed by James Monroe, Secretary of State, Forbes left it, with a copy, which he desired I would certify as correct; which I did. At one O’Clock, as I was just about stepping into the Carriage, three despatches from W. Shaler, Consul General at Algiers, and from Commodore Isaac Chauncey were brought in; which I was obliged to leave then unread, to be in seasonable time for the Queen’s drawing Room— We were there at half past one; and among the first— Before the Drawing-Room, Count Lieven presented me to the Grand Duke Nicholas, who recognized me as an ancienne Connoissance and said that when he had known me at St Petersburg, he little expected to have met me here. He said he was very shortly going away, and was highly gratified with his tour in England, where he had been treated with the kindest possible attentions. The drawing-room commenced precisely at two O’Clock, and continued until half past four. It was far less numerously attended than either of those of the last year— The Dresses of the Ladies were principally of British Manufacture; heavy and inelegant. The Prince Regent, the Dukes of York, Sussex and Gloucester, and Prince Leopold were present—the Princesses Augusta, Elizabeth, Duchess of Gloucester, Sophia of Gloucester, and Charlotte of Wales. She has grown very thin since her marriage; and had the appearance of being out of health and out of humour. The Duke of Sussex appeared in a magnificently gold embroidered Court dress and in Stockings with gold clocks. The Marquis d’Osmond, French Ambassador told him, as if intending to pay him a compliment that that was the fashion at least a century ago. The Duke said that when he assumed the Gala-Court Dress, which he hated he was however determined to have it complete. His Dress was made here, and was a proof that good embroidery could be worked in this Country. The Officers of the Household appeared in new Court Uniforms, of splendid embroidery said to be from Designs by the Prince Regent himself. The principal Conversation at the Drawing Room was about these Dresses. The Duke of Sussex told me that he had of late been very busy, and that these were busy times. Lord and Lady Castlereagh were not there, being in deep mourning for the death of her Mother. After the Drawing Room had closed we were nearly an hour waiting for the Carriage to drive up to the door— I returned to Craven Street and read the despatches from W. Shaler, and
Commodore Chauncey; containing the account of their Negotiation with Algiers; and the reconclusion of the Treaty of Peace, of June 1815 with such a Modification of the 18th. Article, as leaves it compatible with the prior Treaties of Algiers with other powers. At seven O’Clock I went to Lord Castlereagh’s where we had a merely Diplomatic Dinner— All the foreign Ambassadors, Ministers, Chargés d’Affaires and Secretaries of Embassy were there; and also Lord Clancarty, Sir Robert Liston, Lord Walpole, Lord Clive, Mr Hamilton and Mr Planta. Hamilton introduced me to Lord Clancarty, who is the Ambassador to the King of the Netherlands, but now here on a short leave of absence— Baron Rehausen the Swedish Minister told me he was going to Sweden upon a leave of absence in May; and doubted whether he should ever return— That Mr Kantzow the Swedish Minister in the United States, was also going to Sweden on a leave of absence. That Kantzow had written to him that I was to return to America next Spring— He asked me, if I had news of the Ratification of Mr Russell’s Treaty— I had not. He said Kantzow wrote him that some Indian Treaties had been ratified, but the Swedish one had not been acted upon— At table I sat between the Marquis d’Osmond and Poletica; who again told me that he did not believe Daschkoff had been recalled.— that Kosloff certainly had been. That Harris had un peu envenimé that affair, by a Note which he had presented to the Russian Government; and which Nesselrode had told him he had better not present. He also said he understood I should return home in the Spring. The Marquis d’Osmond spoke to me about Count Barbe Marbois, who he said was a very honest Man, un peu sec; and about Dr Franklin and Mademoiselle de Passy— The Portuguese Ambassador Count Palmella asked me to dine with him next Saturday week. I spoke to him about the Chevalier d’Araujo, who he told me was now Minister of the Marine and acting Minister of Foreign Affairs; and whom the king had made Count Da Barca— The dinner was short. At ten O’Clock I went again to Craven Street: changed dress, and went with Smith to the Austrian Ambassador Prince Esterhazy’s Ball— The Grand Duke Nicholas, the Dukes of York and Gloucester were there, and about five hundred other persons— The crowd and heat were excessive. Mr Bourke, the Danish Minister, introduced me to Lord Charlevill— There was some dancing of Quadrilles and Waltzes. At half past twelve I came away; sat down Smith at Craven Street and got home at half past two in the Morning.

21. IX:15. My wife who I hoped was almost recovered from her late illness, was again violently seized last Night, and I found her this morning extremely ill, with a high fever, and alarming inflammatory symptoms. Dr Cooper was here morning and Evening; and bled her in the morning. The abatement of the fever was but little in the course of the day. He left Leaches at Night, to be applied in case of necessity in the Night— I spent the day and Evening almost entirely in her chamber. Walked to Hanwell, and returned across the fields— Received Letters from G. Boyd, T. Aspinwall the Consul, J. Grubb; and T. Smith. The last requesting Letters of introduction for Berlin, St. Petersburg or Vienna.

22. VI:45. My wife was a little better, but still very ill and confined the whole day to her bed. I passed great part of the day, and all the Evening in her chamber. She appeared to be getting better all day; but has still alarming inflammatory symptoms, and returns from time to time of high fever. Cooper was here twice. I had time only for the Journal, and to answer the Letter from J. B. Church at Cork. Walked with George, through Sion House Park and Isleworth. Crossed the Thames in a ferry boat and walked home over Kew Bridge, and through Brentford. 7 Miles— I intended to have gone this day to London; but Mrs Adams was so ill, that I concluded not to leave home. Yesterday the Bill for suspending the Habeas Corpus Act was brought into the House of Lords by Viscount Sidmouth, Secretary of State for the Home Department.

23. VI:30. My wife continued better, but was still confined almost the whole day to her bed. I attended Church with George. Mr Carr read prayers for the first Sunday in Lent, and Mr Milman preached from Hebrews II.18. “For in that he himself hath suffered, being tempted, he is able to succour them that are tempted.” It was only the first part of a discourse. On returning home, I found at the door, J. M. Forbes and J. A. Smith who had just come out from London— They returned however before dinner. I took a walk of an hour with George. Smith brought out Letters from R Boyd, and Mrs C. King to my wife, and a Card of invitation to me from Count Palmella, with some newspapers— I found little time to write in the course of the day and passed the Evening in my wife’s chamber— Read Cobbett’s and Hone’s Register’s, the Examiner and Observer, with last Night’s Courier— Forbes left a seal with me.

24. V:15. Finished the despatch 72 to the Secretary of State, which I have had several days upon hand; and went into London. Mrs Payne went with me. I walked as far as Turnham Green where I was taken up by the Carriage— Sent a packet of the latest National Intelligencers to Mr Poletica, to whom I had promised to lend them; and an answer to the Portuguese Ambassador, Count Palmella’s invitation— I called at Mr Sergeant’s lodgings in Conduit Street, but he was not at home. Mr Storer and J. Sergeant came to the Office.— Sergeant meets with some difficulty in the transaction of his business. Mr Alexander Baring on his return from France, declined being concerned in it. The house of Reid, Irving & Co. disavow the proposals made to the U.S. Bank in their name by Renwick. Their proposals as stated by them, and confirmed by the copy of their Letter to Renwick which they have shewn to Sergeant, are altogether different from those of Renwick to the Bank— This morning they have proposed by an association of the two houses a loan of 3 Millions two hundred thousand dollars; for two years at five per Cent interest, and a Commission of five per Cent to them— This they give as their ultimatum. Mr Sergeant thought the Commission excessive, and considered two per Cent as sufficient for so large a sum. He also thought the bank could procure the dollars elsewhere upon more advantageous terms, particularly at Cadiz or at Gibraltar— He would however agree to these terms; for a smaller sum; for one Million to be taken now, with an option in him to take the rest hereafter, when he may chuse to call for it— But to this they will not agree— His mission was to obtain three Millions two hundred thousand Dollars, two Millions for the Bank of the United States and the rest for other banks. He has a proposal, from the house of Thomas Wilson & Co. to which Gabriel Shaw belongs, to supply him with a Million of Dollars, upon the same terms proposed by the other houses, and he inclined much to accept this offer, because he wished to send off part of the money by a vessel now ready to sail; and because by taking only that sum he will be left unshackled by any Engagement for more. I agreed with him in this opinion— I called at the Engraver Silvester’s for the Seal but it was not ready. Mr Smith answered an invitation from Mrs Porter to dinner on Friday. She had herself called at Craven-Street to make it and to enquire after Mrs. Adams— I got home just before seven— My wife was not so well this day as yesterday; and this Evening had a severe return of her fever.

25. VII. My wife was again better this day, but left her bed only for two or three hours— I wrote several Letters of introduction for Mr T. Smith, to Gentlemen at St. Petersburg, and sent them to him with a Note; and I also answered a Letter from S. Richards at Liverpool; about extra duties, and the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. Walked with George to Brentford and round by Osterley Park; returning by the way of Hanwell— Received a Card from the Lord Mayor, and Lady Mayoress— An invitation to dinner on the 11th. of March— The Newspapers were not brought in till the Evening. The House of Lords last Night passed the Bill for suspending the Habeas Corpus Act— And three Bills to check seditious practices were brought in to the House of Commons.

26. V:30. The Misses Nicholas were here this Morning with Miss Jamieson, to visit Mrs Adams. Miss Jamieson is Governess to the three youngest Misses Perceval, daughters of the late prime Minister who was assassinated in the lobby of the house of Commons by Bellingham— His widow married Sir Henry Carr, Son of the Vicar of Ealing Parish, and a Colonel in the Army. My wife continued better the whole day; and sat up six hours on the Sopha— I intended to have gone into London, but got so much engaged in writing Letters, that the time passed until it was too late— I answered the Card of Invitation from the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress; wrote a Note to Sir Grenville Temple, and answered Letters from C. Hughes, S. O’Malley, I. Chauncey, and W. Shaler— Walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford, and passed the Evening after dinner in my wife’s chamber— Received a Note and a Letter from Mrs Agnes Porter; enclosing for my perusal a Letter from Sir Robert Liston, to Joseph Ewart who was Mrs Porter’s brother. It is dated Turin 26. October 1782. Ewart was then at Berlin private Secretary as appears from the Letter, to Sir John Stepney then British Minister at the Court of Prussia— He had written to Liston, who was Secretary to the British Legation at Turin, for advice, and instructions, for his conduct; Liston having previously been Secretary of Legation at Berlin, while Mr Hugh Elliot was the Minister. The Letter is full of the most excellent advice, given in an easy, familiar style, and with a sportiveness of manner to disguise the gravity of instruction, and it contains notices of many persons at the Court of Berlin whom I afterwards knew there; with observations, not unimportant to the History of the Time, upon the state of the political Relations between Great-Britain and Prussia. He says they were upon a very bad footing, and that it was altogether the fault of the British Ministry— There are several good remarks upon the British diplomatic characters of that day, and upon the manner of doing business in the foreign Department. The advice to Ewart is all prudential and wise; though by no means profound. It is a summary of the Art de parvenir, and appears to have been successfully practised, both by the writer of the Letter, and by his Correspondent. Ewart afterwards became Chargé d’Affaires, and then Minister Plenipotentiary at Berlin; where Mrs Porter says he resided, twelve years. He married there, a Countess Wartensleben, and has now been some years dead— Liston began life as private tutor to Mr H. Elliot, on his travels—then became his private Secretary, when Elliot, barely after coming of age was
appointed British Minister at Munich, to the Elector of Bavaria— When Elliot was transferred to Berlin, Liston went with him, and soon after became his Secretary of Legation. Since then he has constantly been in the Diplomatic Career. Was sometime Minister in the United States, and is now Ambassador at Constantinople, whither at the age of 76 he is to return, next May— His Letter to Ewart gave me occasion for reflection. He blames the British Ministry for the bad footing upon which they were with Prussia. It is well known that one of the causes of that misunderstanding was the outrage by which Mr Elliot became possessed of Mr Arthur Lee’s papers— Elliot himself told me that it had not been done by his orders. That the Papers were brought to him, and he read them; but had no agency in obtaining them. Richards the Swiss, who had been a sort of appendage to the British Missions at Berlin for many years, told me that Liston was the man who had contrived to get the papers; and if so, he was one great cause of the disgust that Frederic had taken against the British; all which though not absolutely incompatible with the contents of this Letter, does not exactly tally with them.

27. VI:30. My wife continues better, but is not yet able to leave her chamber. She was up however the greatest part of this day— I wrote a Note to Mrs A. Porter, and Letters to my brother, and to T. B. Johnson. Received a Letter from General La Fayette, recommending a Mr Descaves who I suppose left it at the Office. Walk with George, on the Windsor Road; beyond the Turnpike. The newspapers did not come in till four in the afternoon; there was a debate in the house of Commons last Night on the first reading of the Bill for suspending the Habeas Corpus Act, which passed however by a Majority of 273 to 98. to the second reading; a debate on the first reading of a bill is unusual— On this occasion however it shewed the strength, and the heat of parties. My evening was occupied in reading this debate—

28. VI: Began a Letter to Jos. Hall at Boston. I have still a considerable file of unanswered Letters, received before the close of the last year, but none of the present year, except such as there are reasons for deferring to answer. Walked from home and was overtaken by the Carriage at the Hammersmith Turnpike. Called at the Whitehall Carpet Manufactory and purchased two Brussels Carpets for G. Boyd. They were to be sent to Feltham’s N. 105. where I called (St. Martin’s Lane) and gave directions to have them shipp’d with other Articles Boyd had ordered there— Then at Christian’s to change the flannel gowns; and at Silvester’s for the Seal which was not yet ready— At Craven Street I found Cards from Mr Descaves, who returns immediately to France, and from Mr Bostwick an American, who is going next week for the United States. A man named Redman, a Lithographic Printer, or Printer upon Stone, came and shewed me many specimens of his Art. He is desirous of going to America. Smith wrote a Note to F. Freeling the Secretary of the general Post-Office, asking him to send me the Packet from Gravesend, which had been charged £10. Postage, which he had reduced to £1.— I went with Smith, and dined at Mrs A. Porter’s 56. Upper-Norton-Street. The company were, William Elliot Lockhart, Member of Parliament for Selkirkshire, a Mr and Mrs Curry of Liverpool; Mr and Mrs Lawson, Mr Boswell, and two or three others. Mr Lawson is an Inspector at the Mint. I mentioned to him that Mr Morrison the Deputy Master and worker of the Mint had sent me a Card to see it last Thursday week, which being the day of the Queen’s Drawing Room, I could not then go— I wished therefore to have the day changed. He said that Thursdays were the usual days for visitors, but I could see all the works by coming to-morrow, upon which I accordingly determined. There was a Lady Lowrie, who came in the Evening. Mrs Lawson sung a Scotch or Irish, and an Italian Song. Mr Lockhart left the table and went away immediately after dinner to attend the house of Commons. I told Mrs Porter that my Son George wished to take a copy of Sir Robert Liston’s Letter to Mr Ewart, but I could not indulge him without her permission which she readily gave. We came away between ten and eleven. I left Smith at Craven Street and reached home about half past twelve.

Day. The average of my rising through the Month has been at VI:14. The range, from IV:15 to IX:15. My wife has been the whole Month ill; and with the exception of one or two days when she rode out, she has been confined to her chamber. My occupations have continued the same as usual, and my course of life very little varied from the preceding Months. The difficulty that I find of writing continues to increase. As the Spring advances I find the relaxation of that Season operating upon me; and with less Industry. I accomplish of course less labour. I can but hope the Industry may revive.
